content:
‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good Clash !

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: lgtm! the alternating left/right took me some time to understand, but interesting problem nonetheless, and appropriate for a CoC imo :-)
Clever idea, just the right level of difficulty.

Thanks for this "Clash-of-Code".
I tested it and could solve it in 5 Minutes and had fun   :-)

I have one textual improvement: 
"... always take letters ... FROM the right and FROM the left ..." 
instead of 
"... always take letters ... TO the right and TO the left ..."

But I am not a native speaker, maybe I am wrong.

Thanks for playing this Clash!
If you liked it, give it an upvote.
If you didn‚Äôt like it‚Ä¶ give it an upvote anyway ‚Äî let‚Äôs not argue ü§°

And here‚Äôs the other Clash‚Ä¶
stronger, faster, and even more ridiculous:
üëâ https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/1363716360651e86028c93849e5b82f5042de9

(Upvoting both increases your natural charisma by +5. It‚Äôs science.)

- I think the order in which characters should be taken from when expanding outward should be flipped: first take the next on the left, then the next on the right. Alternatively, consider rephrasing the explanation of middle-out order (my initial revised explanation was wrong; please see the discussion below).

- Consider including some examples in the problem description for extra clarity.

- Your test cases do not make use of the lowercase English letters. Is this intended?
It seems that your revised explanation doesn't match the cases?

Thanks a lot for your feedback!
You're absolutely right ‚Äî ‚ÄúFROM the right / FROM the left‚Äù is much clearer than ‚ÄúTO the right / TO the left‚Äù.
I‚Äôve updated the statement accordingly. üòä

And thanks for testing the puzzle, glad to hear you had fun with it!

I just noticed that the order is different for odd and even-length strings. The odd-length strings take the middle letter first, then take alternately from the right, then from the left. On the other hand, the even-length strings take the middle two letters first, then take alternately from the left, then from the right.

Not sure which order, if one is to be chosen among the two, is the intended one. Alternatively, I would think the instructions would have to be written separately for odd and even-length strings.

That's over-complicating things.

For odd-length strings, take the middle letter first.
For even-length strings, take the left middle letter first.
From there, take alternately the right and the left letters.

That works as well, but the current description will need to be updated. The part on "start with the left middle, then the right middle" sounds like the order is to take both middle letters (for even-length strings) first, before considering the alternating right-left sequence.
I agree; the explanation needs to be updated. I also agree with the second and third points in your first comment (regarding examples and letter case).

Thanks a lot for all your detailed feedback! 
I‚Äôve simplified and clarified the rule in the statement to make the logic consistent and easier to understand:

For odd-length strings ‚Üí start from the middle, then alternate right ‚Üí left ‚Üí right ‚Üí left‚Ä¶

For even-length strings ‚Üí start from the left middle, then alternate right ‚Üí left ‚Üí right ‚Üí left‚Ä¶

I also updated the examples and test cases accordingly (ABCDE ‚Üí CDBEA, wxyz ‚Üí xywz, hello ‚Üí lleoh) and kept the wording aligned with the constraints and formatting guidelines.
Everything should now match the actual program behavior.

Thanks again for helping refine this contribution!
